## 4.1 Introduction

In this week we focus on advanced data manipulation in R. We will continue using the `dplyr` package in the `tidyverse`. 

### 4.1.1 Download data

We will be working with the emissions dataset, which you can download from my github site:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
emissions <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/AubreyMpungose/data-science-course/main/weeks/data/emissions.csv")
```
:::


We will be working with the carbon emissions dataset. You can examine the dataset using the `str()` fucntion:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
str(emissions)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
'data.frame':	15448 obs. of  6 variables:
 $ country  : chr  "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" "Afghanistan" ...
 $ continent: chr  "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" "Asia" ...
 $ year     : int  1992 1992 1992 1992 1992 1992 1992 1992 1992 1992 ...
 $ pop      : int  16317921 16317921 16317921 16317921 16317921 16317921 16317921 16317921 16317921 16317921 ...
 $ gdpPercap: num  649 649 649 649 649 ...
 $ co2_pp   : num  0.0568 0.1633 0.0626 0.2965 0.0685 ...
```
:::
:::
